items.item_details: For next month Board meeting----- Original Message -----From: Corbett, ShariTo: AH All UsersSent: Wed Mar 19 16:48:34 2008Subject: District Competition for Principal's TrophyLadies and Gentlemen, On Saturday, our Andrew Hill JROTC Falcon battalion won the ESUHSD competition for the Principal's Trophy! The competition started in September and ended this last Saturday.  The categories are: Academics, Color Guard presentation, Physical Fitness, Precision Drill, Rifle Drill, and 3 Ball Soccer (3 soccer balls on the field with the two competing schools providing 35 players a piece--continuous action).    Oak Grove led for the first part of the year and we pulled past them in January and managed to hold onto our lead Saturday. We won by 4 points. We are very proud of these young leaders and great citizens!  It was pouring rain when we began the physical fitness competition and continued to pour while they did their chin ups, push-ups and curl-ups.  The weather cleared as we began the 10 person 440 relay race.  Honors for Individual Stand outs are: Ashley Nguyen was Best Female Overall Athlete Alan Duong, 1st place Individual Precision Drill Tommy Nguyen, 2nd place Individual Precision Drill Saturdays Precision Drill was all Navy commands and the fact that the last two standing in the Seniors competition were Army students from Andrew Hill was thrilling.  The students had 8 judges and started with over 50 competitors.  Many students were removed for something as simple as their thumbs being out of place.  Tommy Nguyen was so moved he was crying.  Tommy has competed for 4 years and it was his first medal.  A very moving moment since he is so silly most of the time--I thought he was faking at first. Please tell them Congratulations as you see them on Campus the next couple days. Thank You !

items.item_details: SUBJECT:	Measure E – Citizens’ Bond Oversight CommitteeThe Board certified the Measure E election results at the March 20 Board meeting.  The Education Code (sec. 15278) requires that the Board establish and appoint members to an independent Citizens’ Oversight Committee (“CBOC”) within 60 days of the certification of the election results (i.e., in this case by May 19, 2008).  The CBOC must consist of at least seven members (the Board may appoint more members if it chooses) to serve for a term of two years without compensation and for no more than two consecutive terms.  The CBOC must be comprised of at least the following:1.	One member who is active in a business organization representing the business community located within the ESUHSD district;2.	One member who is active in a senior citizens’ organization;3.	One member who is a parent or a guardian of a student enrolled in the district; and4.	One member who is both a parent or guardian of a student enrolled in the district and active in a parent-teacher organization.No employee or official of the district, vendor, contractor or consultant of the district may be appointed to the CBOC.The current Measure G Oversight Committee has extensive and valuable experience in overseeing a large-scale bond program.  To capitalize on that experience and to ensure a successful beginning to the Measure E bond program, Administration recommends that the Board establish the Measure E CBOC and appoint the current members of the Measure G Oversight Committee to also sit as the Measure E CBOC for a term of two years.  Once the Measure E CBOC is established and appointed, the Board can thereafter, if it chooses, appoint additional individuals to that committee.FISCAL IMPACT FUNDING SOURCENone	NoneRECOMMENDATIONEstablish the Measure E CBOC and appoint the current Measure G Bond Oversight Committee as the initial Measure E CBOC.

items.item_details: 6EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT	Board Meeting of April 17, 2008	Agenda Item:  8.4TO:	Board of TrusteesFROM:	Bob Nunez, SuperintendentSUBJECT:	Adopt Resolution 2007/2008-40 -- Declaring Intention to Reimburse Certain Expenditures from Proposed Tax Exempt FinancingAdministration has begun the process towards issuing Measure E bonds.  Administration recommends that the Board adopt and approve the attached Reimbursement Resolution which will allow the District to be reimbursed for costs incurred by the District in connection with the issuance of the bonds but which were incurred by the District in advance of the bond issuance.FISCAL IMPACT FUNDING SOURCENone	NoneRECOMMENDATIONAdopt Resolution 2007/2008- 40.  EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTRESOLUTION NO. 2007-2008-40RESOLUTION OF THE BOARD OF trusteeS OF THE EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT DECLARING ITS INTENTION TO REIMBURSE CERTAIN EXPENDITURES FROM PROPOSED TAX EXEMPT FINANCING AS REQUIRED BY UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF TREASURY REGULATIONS SECTION 1.150-2 WHEREAS, the Board of Trustees (the “Board”) of the East Side Union High School District (the “District”) desires to undertake the list of school facilities projects (the “Projects”) set forth in Appendix A hereto; andWHEREAS, the District reasonably expects, as of the date hereof, to finance expenditures relating to the Project by authorizing the sale and delivery of one or more series of Obligations (as defined below); andWHEREAS, United States Income Tax Regulations section 1.150-2 provides generally that proceeds of tax-exempt debt used to reimburse expenditures paid prior to the date of issuance of such debt are treated as expended only if certain procedures are followed, one of which is a requirement that (with certain exceptions), prior to the payment of any such expenditures, the issuer declares an intention to reimburse such expenditure; andWHEREAS, the District reasonably expects to expend some funds in connection with the Project prior to the issuance of debt for such purpose; andWHEREAS, the District reasonably expects, as of the date hereof, to reimburse such expenditures by allocating a portion of the proceeds of the Obligations to the reimbursement of such expenditures; andWHEREAS, it is in the public interest and for the public benefit that the District declares its official intent to reimburse the expenditures referenced herein.NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED by the GOVERNING BOARD of the EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT as follows:Section 1. 		The District intends to issue one or more series of obligations (the “Obligations”) the proceeds of which will be used to modernize, replace, renovate, construct, equip, furnish, rebuild the Projects, to acquire real property for future educational facilities and to acquire and install furniture, fixtures and equipment at the Projects of the District as set forth in Appendix A.Section 2. 		The District hereby declares that it reasonably expects to (i) pay certain costs of the Projects prior to the date of issuance of the Obligations; and (ii) use a portion of the proceeds of the Obligations for reimbursement of expenditures for the Projects that are paid prior to the issuance of the Obligations.Section 3. 	The aggregate maximum principal amount of the Obligations to be issued is expected not to exceed $349,000,000.  Section 4. 	In addition to reimbursing the District, the proceeds from the Obligations are anticipated to be used for costs and expenses related to the Projects, funding reserve funds and paying certain costs of issuance related thereto.Section 5. 	The reimbursement allocation to be made with respect to an expenditure will occur not later than eighteen (18) months after the later of (i) the date on which the expenditure is paid, or (ii) the date on which the related Project is placed in service, but in no event more than 3 years after the expenditure is paid.Section 6. 	This Resolution expresses the District’s expectations as of this date with respect to the financing of the Projects.  Future events or extraordinary circumstances beyond the control of the District may result in the Projects being financed in a manner other than as described in this Resolution, and nothing contained herein constitutes an irrevocable commitment by the District to issue the Obligations.Section 7. 	All actions heretofore taken by the officers, or their respective designees, employees and agents of the Board of Trustees of the District in connection with the financing of the Projects are hereby ratified and confirmed.Section 8. 	This Resolution shall take effect immediately upon its adoption. **********The foregoing Resolution was adopted by the Board of Trustees of the East Side Union High School District of Santa Clara County, being the Board authorized by law to make the designations therein contained by the following vote, on April 17, 2008.AYES:	________NOES:	________ABSTAIN:	________ABSENT:	________						____________________________________						Clerk of the Board of Trustees						of the East Side Union High School DistrictAPPENDIX ARENOVATION AND REPAIR OF EXISTING SCHOOLS AND FACILITIES AND ACQUISITION AND CONSTRUCTION OF NEW SCHOOL FACILITIESBond proceeds will be expended to modernize, replace, renovate, construct, equip, rebuild and furnish the District’s education facilities, to acquire land for new school and educational facility construction. items.item_details: East Union High School District, Franklin McKinley School District and San Jose / Evergreen College have been collaborating to develop an early college middle school / high school.  The program is its very early stages of discussion looks to:	Make higher education more accessible, affordable, and attractive by bridging the divide between high school and college;	Provide the guidance and support from adults through the first two years of college;	Demonstrate new ways of integrating levels of schooling. This resolution requests the Board to direct the Superintendent and staff to continue development of the New Partnership School Design (7-13) planning process until such time as the formal proposal is brought back to the Board for consideration and approval. Fiscal Impact Funding SourceNone							NoneRecommendation	It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2007/2008-36 as an Endorsement of the New Partnership School (7-13) Planning Process.East Side Union High School DistrictResolution # 2007-2008 - 39Endorsement of the New Partnership School (7-13) Planning ProcessWHEREAS, the two public schools (East Side Union High School District and Franklin McKinley School District) and the community college district (San Jose /Evergreen Community College District) are planning an innovative New Partnership School (grades 7-13) in San Jose, California, that has a tentative starting date of August, 2009; andWHEREAS, both Superintendents, the Community College Chancellor and College President and staff have been involved in the initial design of the New Partnership School (from this point on know as the PARTNERS; andWHEREAS, the PARTNERS are committed to effectively deal with the achievement gap in San Jose, California, and offer students and their families the very best opportunity to have access to a university degree and a professional career; and WHEREAS, Education Week now ranks California 46th in the nation and per-pupil spending, and is lacking new school designs or initiatives that maximizes resources between educational partners and community resources; and WHEREAS, the PARTNERS are committed to design a New Partnership School, covering grades 7 through grades 13; andWHEREAS, most of the cost for planning and development of the New Partnership School will be paid out of one or more foundation grants, and may involve other critical partners in the region (E.G., universities and businesses); andWHEREAS, The PARTNERS are committed to include some of the best secondary school design features in the world, and plan to study best practices nationally, as well as overseas. These include: a) the small school design; b) teachers staying with the same group of students for two or more years; c) contextual learning focus (e.g., authentic assessments); d) service learning and career exploration; e) early college access (11th and 12th grades); and f) Modern Apprenticeship experiences before graduation. Because of their past and current record of high academic expectations and achievement for all students, the PARTNERS have the luxury of carefully thinking through these ideas before moving ahead with an instructional and organizational design to bring back to their respective governing boards; andTHEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, the East Side Union High School Board, endorses and supports the continual development of the New Partnership School Design (7-13) and directs the Superintendent and staff  to continue their planning process, until such time as the formal proposal is brought back to the Board for final approval.PASSED AND ADOPTED THIS 17TH day of April 2008, by the Governing Board of East Side Union High School District Of Santa Clara County, California.I,     George Shirakwa,   Clerk of the Governing Board of East Side Union High School District , of Santa Clara, County of California, certify that the foregoing is a full, true and correct copy of a resolution adopted by the said Board at the April 4, 2008 meeting thereof held at a regular public place of meeting and the resolution is on file in the office of said Board._______________________________			_________________          Clerk’s Signature						Date

items.item_details: The Instructional Policies Committee (IPC) has reviewed the Tourism Geography & World Cultures course listed below.  This course was piloted during the 2007-2008 school year.  The course description is included for your review.  At this time, the members of IPC recommend approval of this course.Tourism Geography & World Cultures: This course surveys the nature of tourism as an applied field of geography and its impact on the cultural and physical landscape. Tourism Geography and World Cultures explores the impact of tourism around the world and its costs such as the diversion of scarce resources, commercialization of local cultures, and environmental degradation.  This course introduces students to the importance of geography in the Hospitality and Tourism industry, placing specific geographic regions in the context of traveler’s interests and presenting the businesses established in specific regions to serve this interest. Tourism Geography encourages students to consider the way in which geography has impacted the way in which we organize our world and the manner in which specific cultures have formed as a result of geographic divisions and boundaries. Students explore a variety of domestic and foreign destinations and the tourist-related activities associated with these destinations. Finally, students get the chance to learn about the types of careers available to them in the Hospitality and Tourism industry that require specific geographic knowledge and expertise.FISCAL IMPACT FUNDING SOURCESN/A					N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the course above.
